BY JOE LEVINE
The first annual Johns Hopkins University Arts Festival will
open on Wednesday evening,
March 3. with a reading by
novelist and short-story writer
Donald Barthelme, at 8:00 p.m.
in the Listening/Viewing Room.

The festival, which will
include a series of readings,
panel discussions, and dramatic
presentations, has grown out of
an idea by the Career Planning
Office, and is aimed at bringing
writing students in closer contact with professionals in the
field.

Charles Village Parking Lot
The Charles Village Civic Association is presently investigating the construction of a residential parking garage in the
vicinity of 3300 Calvert Street. A proposal was made to raze nine
row houses in this area to construct a ground level garage. No
plans have been adopted, and the Civic Association is not endorsing the possibility of the construction.

Traffic Problems On Charles Street
The City Department of Transit and Traffic is currently
reviewing an extensive study on traffic problems on North
Charles Street. An inordinate number of accidents occur on
Charles Street each year, possibly due to the flow of north- and
southbound traffic in adjacent lanes. The department is considering rerouting traffic, or installing "rumble bumps": grates at
intersections that signal the flow of traffic to other cars.

Students Will Attempt To Change Tenure Policy
BY BRUCE ALPERT
The student members of the
Committee on Undergraduate
Studies are currently finalizing
a proposal which they will
submit to the Committee which
would make teaching a criterion
for tenure.
Though the content of the
proposal will not be available for
publication until it is presented
to the CUS at its next meeting
on March 4, Doug Fellman,
chairman of the Student Council's Education Committee and
author of the proposal, states
that it will be one of the most
significant as well as controversial moves by the Student
Council this year.
Another member of the
CUS, Student Council president
Chuck Peifer, maintains that he
is going to push very strongly for
passage of this proposal and will
attempt to force the Committee
to meet every other week until
this issue is settled. lie believes
that the proposal has a good
chance of being approved by the
CUS and sent to the Academic
Council for approval as University policy.
While the tenure policy at
Johns Hopkins has been the
subject of much criticism over
the years, no positive action on
this matter has been taken by
the Academic Council, according
to both Peifer and Felimn.
While Fellman states that he is
not sure his current actions will
actually force some positive
action, he states that "at least it
will start them [the CUS and
the Academic Council] talking
about it." He states that one of
his main objectives is to bring
the question of tenure up for
revision for the first time.
, The policy by which the
Oniversity grants tenure and
promotions to its faculty has
been the subject of several
reports to the Academic Council
over the last ten years. In
February of 1972 the Council
received the Final Report of the
Blue Ribbon Committee on
Undergraduate Education of The
Johns Hopkins University. In
this report, the Committee
stated that ". . .about half of a
faculty member's time is supposed to be spc it doing scholarly research. It is on this that he
is largely judged for promotion
and salary. . .If the quality of

undergraduate teaching is to
improve, the University must.. .
.find a broader means of evaluating faculty members in order to
reward them for meeting the
University's needs."
The report continued that
"unless a broader system of
evaluation is instituted, there is
little chance of changing present
teaching practices." In light of
this observation, which the Committee made by examining the
results of a survey answered by
half of the University's undergraduates, several recommenda-

tions were forwarded to the
Academic Council. One recommendation asked that "the University adopt appropriate methods for recognizing and rewarding quality and innovation
in teaching. We urge the formation of a faculty-student-administration committee to establish
a proper system for teaching
evaluation in all undergraduate
courses. . .We strongly urge that
every student have an opportunity to contribute to this evaluation process and that each
department take the initiative in

appraising and promoting better
teaching." This recommendation concluded by declaring that
"to be meaningful, we propose
that teaching evaluation be a
significant component in judging
faculty promotions and salaries."
In May of 1976, the Student Council attempted to sway
the Academic Council into revising some of its rules on tenure
and promotions. In a letter sent
to the Academic Council dated
May 11, 1976, the Student
Council recommended that the

memorandum which outlines
"procedures for consideration of
faculty appointments and promotions" be reworded to state
that evaluations of a candidate's
teaching would be considered in
determining such advances of
faculty members. Says the Student Council memorandum, "Information on the candidate's
undergraduate teaching, including Course Evaluation and the
results of other surveys by
undergraduates, when available,
shall be included in the file of
the candidate. . ."

BY JANICE BRILL
Participation in the sixth
Annual Catholic University of
America (CUA) Invitational
wrapped up the 1982 women's
basketball season for Hopkins.
In first round play the Jays
faced hosting Catholic on Feb.
19. Unable to redeem an earlier
loss to the Cardinals, Hopkins
was defeated 84-64. Saturday
the women beat Marymount
66-62 and finished the six-team
tournament in fifth place.
George Mason emerged as tournament champion by a slim
one-point margin over Loyola.
Distinguishing herself among the
the many participants was Hopkins' Geraldine Klauber, who
was selected to the 1982 CUA
All-Tournament Team.
Including tournament competition, the Jays' final season
record stands at 8 wins, 11
losses, a significant improvement
over last year's 4-13 record.
Leading scorer was freshman
Dawn Richards who averaged

16.4 points per game and
accumulated a grand total of
295 points. Klauber and Amy
Buchanan also had high scoring
seasons averaging 14.7 and 11.4
points per game, respectively.
The same trio also lead in the
department:
rebounding
Richards on top averaging 8.5
rebounds per game, followed by
Buchanan (8.2) and Klauber
(7.4).
Completing her first season
as head coach, Kay Fowler
expressed much enthusiasm.
Team spirit was a key factor in
holding the Jays together
through the losses, and four of'
the losses were close games
which evidenced the team's
potential.
Five players were
veterans of Hopkins' losing past
and had to overcome that
mental block. Easy early-season
victories were stacked before
tough games such as Trinity
(76-46) and Mt. Vernon (78-21)
and a 90-60 loss to Notre Dame.
The same occured with wins
over Trinity again (79-34) and
Wilson (68-38) before a 96-43

Gettysburg upset. Fowler wishes
to eliminate the weaker teams
from next year's schedule and is
applying for admission to the
Southwestern division of the
Atlantic Conference
Middle
(MAC). The only requirements
would be the addition of Lebanon Valley and Franklin &
Marshall to the schedule. This
move will be a step in the right
direction because it will provide
more incentive to win, and the
MAC recognizes individuals in
the conference.
The season has been one of
learning for coach and team
alike. Fowler had to adjust to a
new league and new team.
Hopkins will miss starter Sue
Tyler and rotating first substitute Kathleen King, both of
whom will be graduating this
spring.
However, there is a
promising pool of young talent
to take over.
